key_title: Key to the species of Callistemon

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Myrtaceae

source.author: Spencer, R.D.
source.title: Callistemon
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Spencer, R.D. (1996). Callistemon. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers red or pink
Flowers cream to yellow
Leaves mostly less than 3 mm wide; capsules mostly less than 5 mm wide
Leaves mostly more than 3 mm wide; capsules ususally more than 5 mm wide (3–5 mm wide in C. sieberi)
Leaf margins not inrolled; hypanthium initally hairy, soon glabrous or sparsely hairy
Leaves terete or with margin inrolled; hypanthium densely pubescent
Hypanthium pubescent; filaments reddish to pinkish purple
Hypanthium more or less glaborus (axis and sepals often pubescent), or if ever pubescent then filaments pale pink
Leaves mostly narrowly oblanceolate, roughly gland-dotted; anthers yellow
Leaves narrowly oblanceolate, narrowly elliptic, narrowly lanceolate or linear, not roughly gland-dotted; anthers pink to purple, rarely yellowish
Leaves mostly 3–4 mm wide; flower spikes mostly less than 5 cm diam.; filaments mauve
Leaves mostly more than 4 mm wide; flower spikes usually more than 5 cm diam.; filaments dark pinkish-purple or red
Leaves more or less linear, largest leaves more than 7 cm long; cultivated plants
Leaves more or less oblanceolate or lanceolate, largerst leaves not longer than 7 cm
Leaves linear-lanceolate to broadly lanceolate; filaments dark pinkish-purple; restricted to the Upper Genoea River
Leaves mostly oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic; filaments bright red; relatively widespread in moist or near-swamp habitats in East Gippsland
Oil glands visible on the lower surface or obscure; filaments pink or yellow
Oil glands visible on both leaf surfaces; filaments crimson or purple-red
Large, erect shrub or tree to c. 10 m high; leaves dull, usually more than 4 mm wide; flower spikes more than 3 cm diam.; western Victoria
Sreading shrub or tree to 3 m high (rarely to 8 m high); leaves sublustrous, usually less than 4 mm wide; flower spikes up to 3 cm diam.; eastern Victoria
Multi-stemmed shrub 1–3 m high; leaves commonly up to 6 mm wide; capsules more than 6 mm diam.; Betka River
Usually single or few-stemmed shrub to 1.2 m high; leaves rarely more than 4 mm wide; capsules less than 6 mm diam.; Boggy Creek Gorge
Leaves less than 3 mm wide
Leaves more than 3 mm wide
Bark soft and papery; largest leaves up to 14 cm long, young leaves purplish pink; cultivated plants
Bark hard, sometimes fissured; largest leaves not more than 7 cm long, or if ever slighlty more than 7 cm long then new growth with dense silvery hair
Flower spikes 3–3.5 cm wide; oil glands often prominent; filaments mostly yellowish
Flower spikes less than 3 cm wide; oil glands mostly inconspicuous; filaments cream to pink
